Question:

Answer:
Its essence is wisdom.
Because of the abundance of the power of mindfulness in that group of mind, it is called the knowledge of past lives.
Like the mindfulness of the body, the mindfulness of breathing, and the removal of the notion of form, it is the same.
This is the essence of the knowledge of one's own nature and past lives, and so on, explained in detail.
The reason for its essence has already been explained. Now, why is it called the knowledge of one's own nature and past lives?
Answer:
Because one attains this knowledge upon birth, it is called the knowledge of one's own nature and past lives.
Moreover, because one can know the nature of wholesome mind, the nature of unwholesome mind, and the nature of indeterminate mind, it is called the knowledge of one's own nature and past lives.
Furthermore, past dharmas are called self-nature because they do not change again. Being able to know this dharma is called the knowledge of the arising of self-nature recollection.

Again, some say: If one repairs a narrow place to make it spacious, by this karma, one is not cramped in the mother's womb. By this karma, one can produce such a reward.
Again, some say: If a person gives delicious food to others, that karma attains such a reward.

If sentient beings do not create karma that harms others, they will be spacious in their mother's womb and not be afflicted by wind, heat, cold, illness, fat, or blood. If they emerge from the womb, they will also not be squeezed by the birth canal. For this reason, they do not forget what they have thought of.
All sentient beings, if they are not squeezed by the birth canal, all have the wisdom of remembering past lives;
Because they are squeezed by the birth canal, they all lose what they have thought of.

Among all conditioned and unconditioned dharmas, two dharmas are the essence of liberation:
Among conditioned dharmas, it is liberation within the great earth, and among unconditioned dharmas, it is cessation through deliberation.
Liberation within the great earth is of two kinds: defiled and undefiled. The defiled one is wrong liberation, and the undefiled one is right liberation.
Right liberation is of two kinds: with outflows and without outflows.
The one with outflows is associated with the immeasurable of impurity, etc., and the one without outflows is of learners and post-learners.
The learner is associated with the perseverance for the cognition of the factors with regard to suffering up to the diamond-like concentration. The post-learner is the arhat.

Arhats are of two kinds: those liberated at times and those liberated not at times. Those liberated at times are the five kinds of arhats, while those liberated not at times are the one kind of arhat.
These two kinds of arhats, by detaching from desires and attaining freedom from desires, are liberated in mind, and by detaching from ignorance, they are liberated in wisdom.

The question says:
Why is it called time liberation?
The answer says:
Because it is obtained in dependence on time, it is called time.

Those who depend on bedding, if they obtain thick and soft bedding, they can attain liberation, if not, they cannot attain liberation.
Those who depend on the Dharma, if they hear the Dharma expounded by a skillful teacher, they can attain liberation, if not, they cannot attain liberation.
Those who depend on place, if the place is quiet and free from disturbances, they can attain liberation, if not, they cannot attain liberation.
Those who depend on people, if they obtain good-natured people who are easy to live with, they can attain liberation, if not, they cannot attain liberation.
Why is it called non-time liberation?
Answer:
Because one attains liberation without waiting for the right time, it is called non-time liberation.
Not waiting for the right time means not waiting for the six conditions, namely clothing, food, bedding, Dharma, place, and people.

Not waiting for the right time for clothing means that wearing discarded clothes can cultivate good dharmas, which is superior to one liberated at a specific time wearing clothes worth a hundred thousand in value.
Not waiting for mealtime means that even if one eats inferior coarse food, one can still cultivate the Way, which is superior to the time-liberated one who eats a hundred flavors of food.
Not waiting for bedding time means that sitting on a stone one can still cultivate the Way, which is superior to the time-liberated one who sits on thick soft cushions.
Not waiting for Dharma-speaking time means that if one hears the Dharma spoken by a person without skillful means, one can quickly enter meditation.
Not waiting for direction time means that if there are many noisy sounds in a certain direction, one can quickly enter concentration.
Not waiting for people time means that if one obtains a person of bad nature who is difficult to live with, and yet lives together with them, one can quickly enter concentration.
Furthermore, one is called time-liberated because one attains this Dharma through a narrow path.

Question:
Why is liberation at times a cherished dharma?
Answer:

Like a person who has only one eye, all the members of his family protect it together, not allowing cold, heat, wind, or dust to damage it.
It is the same for him.

Furthermore, the arhat liberated at times does not have mastery over liberation, and it is only after much effort that he can make it present. Because he produces it in the present, his mind experiences joy, and he is called one who loves the Dharma.

The arhat liberated regardless of occasion has mastery over liberation, and it is not after much effort that he can make it present. Because he produces it in the present, his mind does not experience joy, and he is not called one who loves the Dharma.
Furthermore, the arhat liberated at times has retrogression, and because he fears retrogression, he frequently produces liberation and makes it present.
The arhat liberated regardless of occasion has no retrogression, and because he does not fear retrogression, he does not frequently produce liberation and make it present.

Because of these wholesome roots that detest the noble path, he does not love this Dharma.
The arhat liberated at times does not have these wholesome roots, and therefore he cherishes this Dharma.

Question:

Furthermore, one who has already severed afflictions never regresses again, and is thus called immovable.
It is like a skilled archer who shoots straight at the target, and is said to be unmoving.

Question:

The arhat liberated at times cultivates two kinds of wisdom, namely the knowledge of destruction and the right view of the post-learner.

Is the liberation at all times associated with the knowledge of destruction and the knowledge of non-arising?
Four alternatives are extensively made.
As stated in the sutra:

As for the knowledge of exhaustion, when an arhat liberated at times brings forth the vajra-like concentration for a single instant, the knowledge of exhaustion arises in succession and appears before him.
From the knowledge of exhaustion, either the right view of the post-learner arises or a worldly thought.

An arhat liberated independent of time brings forth the vajra-like concentration, and the knowledge of exhaustion appears before him for a single instant, and in succession the knowledge of non-arising appears before him.

Question:

Some say that the names themselves are the difference, this is called the knowledge of exhaustion, this is called the knowledge of non-arising.

Furthermore, that which is included in the path of liberation and the path of progress is called the knowledge of extinction, and that which is only included in the path of progress is called the knowledge of non-arising.

Furthermore, the knowledge of extinction belongs to the five kinds of arhats, while the knowledge of non-arising belongs to the one kind of arhat, namely the one whose mind is liberated without further clinging.
This is the distinction between the knowledge of extinction and the knowledge of non-arising.

Why is it so?

When a practitioner first enters the noble path, he contemplates the fruit and also contemplates the fruit upon emerging, just as when a poisonous arrow strikes an animal, the poison spreads throughout its body.
Later, when it dies, the poisonous qi returns to the wound.
It is the same for him.
Some also say it is the inferential knowledge of the origin [of suffering].
Why is it so?
Because when practitioners enter the noble path they contemplate the fruits, and when they emerge from the noble path they contemplate the causes.
Thus, the dharmas of birth and death are either causes or fruits. If one knows the causes and knows the fruits, then the path of birth and death is severed, which is called the end of suffering.
The judges say:
One should say:
This is the inferential knowledge of suffering and the inferential knowledge of accumulation.
